Subjective: Right-sided back pain, 1.5 weeks, worsening. Radiates down right leg (posterior thigh, lateral lower leg, to foot). Pain constant, severe, very uncomfortable. Unable to sleep for nights. Temporarily stopped working (supermarket, lifting heavy things) due to pain; unable to exercise. Tried max dose Paracetamol and Ibuprofen, ineffective. Right lateral lower leg sensation duller/different; tingling in painful area. Strength present, but pain limits movement. No saddle anesthesia, no bladder/bowel dysfunction. Request: Wants pain relief, wants to sleep, asks about specialist/scan/surgery. No smoking/alcohol mentioned.
Objective: Pain noted getting onto exam couch. Legs: No unusual findings. Back: No unusual findings, normal on vertebral palpation. Pain on palpation right gluteal/sacral area. Right Straight Leg Raise painful; Left SLR not painful. Sensation: Right lateral lower leg duller/different. Strength: Bilateral leg strength preserved, pain noted during testing. Reflexes: Bilateral Achilles and plantar reflexes normal.
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, susp. Herniated Nucleus Pulposus (HNP). No signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: Explanation: Suspected HNP, disc compressing nerve, causing nerve pain, takes weeks-months to resolve. Surgery not first-line.
Medication: Start Pregabalin. Slow dose build-up due to side effects. Driving restriction: No driving for 1 week after starting/dose increase, or if side effects.
Lifestyle: Physiotherapy recommended for exercises to improve back flexibility, hoping disc shrinks/repositions.
Safety Netting: Contact GP/out-of-hours service if symptoms worsen, new saddle anesthesia, bladder/bowel dysfunction, or significant leg weakness (no strength).
Follow-up: Telephone appointment in 1 week to review pain relief progress. No immediate scan/surgery needed.
